And when you please to do her so much honour.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Come, let us dispatch.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: In troth I have heard her say, Sir,
Of a fat man she has not seen a sweeter.
But in this business, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Let us do it first
And then dispute, the Ladies use may long for it.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: All secrecy she would desire, she told me
How wise you are.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: We are not wise to talk thus,
Carry her the gold, I will look her out a Jewel,
Shall sparkle like her eyes, and thee another,
Come prithee come, I long to serve thy Lady,
Long monstrously, now valour I shall meet ye,
You that dare Dukes.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Green goose you are now in sippets.

div1.stage: Enter the Duke, Sanchio, Juan, Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He shall not have his will, I shall prevent him,
I have a toy here that will turn the tide,
And suddenly, and strangely, hear Don Juan,
Do you present it to him.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A fellow founded out of Charity,
And moulded to the height contemn his maker,
Curb the free hand that framed him? This must not be.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: That such an oyster shell should hold a pearl,
And of so rare a price in prison,
Was she made to be the matter of her own undoing,
To let a slovenly unwieldy fellow,
Unruly and self willed, dispose her beauties?
We suffer all Sir in this sad Eclipse,
She should shine where she might show like herself,
An absolute sweetness, to comfort those admire her,
And shed her beams upon her friends.
We are gulled all,
And all the world will grumble at your patience,
If she be ravished thus.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Never fear it Sanchio,
We will have her free again, and move at Court
In her clear orb: but one sweet handsomeness,
To bless this part of Spain and have that slubbered?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: It is every good man's cause, and we must stir in it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I will warrant he shall be glad to please us,
And glad to share too, we shall hear anon
A new song from him, let us attend a little.

div1.stage: Enter Leon and Juan, with a commission.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Colonel, I am bound to you for this nobleness,
I should have been your officer, it is true Sir,
And a proud man I should have been to have served you,
It has pleased the King out of his boundless favours,
To make me your companion, this commission
Gives me a troop of horse.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I do rejoice at it,
And am a glad man we shall gain your company,
I am sure the King knows you are newly married,
And out of that respect gives you more time Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Within four days I am gone, so he commands me,
And it is not mannerly for me to argue it,
The time grows shorter still, are your goods ready?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: They are aboard.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Do you hear ho, go carry this unto your Mistress Sir,
And let her see how much the King has honoured me,
Bid her be lusty, she must make a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Lorenzo, Sir,
Go take down all the hangings,
And pack up all my cloths, my plate and Jewels,
And all the furniture that is portable,
Sir when we lie in garrison, it is necessary
We keep a handsome port, for the Kings honour;
And do you hear, let all your Ladies wardrobe
Be safely placed in trunks, they must along too.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Whither must they go Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To the wars, Lorenzo,
And you and all, I will not leave a turn-spit,
That has one dram of spleen against a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why then Saint Jaques hey, you have made us all Sir,
And if we leave ye -- does my Lady go too?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The stuff must go tomorrow towards the sea Sir,
All, all must go.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why Pedro, Vasco, Dego,
Come help me, come come boys, soldadoes, comrades,
We will slay these beer-bellied rogues, come away quickly.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: He has taken a brave way to save his honour,
And cross the Duke, now I shall love him dearly,
By the life of credit thou art a noble Gentleman.

div1.stage: Enter Margarita led by two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why how now wife, what, sick at my preferment?
This is not kindly done.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: No sooner love ye,
Love ye entirely Sir, brought to consider
The goodness of your mind and mine own duty,
But lose you instantly, be divorced from ye?
This is a cruelty, I will to the King
And tell him it is unjust to part two souls,
Two minds so nearly mixed.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By no means sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: If he were married but four days as I am.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He would hang himself the fifth, or fly his Country.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: He would make it treason for that tongue that durst
But talk of war, or anything to vex him,
You shall not go.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed I must sweet wife,
What shall I lose the King for a few kisses?
We will have enough.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I will to the Duke my cousin, he shall to the King.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He did me this great office,
I thank his grace for it, should I pray him now,
To undo it again? fie it were a base discredit.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Would I were able Sir to bear you company,
How willing should I be then, and how merry!
I will not live alone.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Be in peace, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: What knocking is this? O Heaven my head, why rascals
I thinks the war is begun in the house already.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The preparation is, they are taking down,
And packing up the hangings, plate and Jewels,
And all those furnitures that shall befit me
When I lie in garrison.

sp.speaker: Coachm.
sp.l: Must the Coach go too Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How will your Lady pass to the sea else easily?
We shall find shipping for it there to transport it.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I go? alas!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will have a main care of ye,
I know ye are sickly, he shall drive the easier,
And all accommodation shall attend ye.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Would I were able,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come I warrant ye,
Am not I with ye sweet? are her clothes packed up,
And all her linen? give your maids direction,
You know my time is but short, and I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Let me have a nurse,
And all such necessary people with me,
And an easy bark.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It shall not trot I warrant ye,
Curvet it may sometimes.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I am with child Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: At four days warning? this is something speedy,
Do you conceive as our jennets do with a west wind?
My heir will be an arrant fleet one Lady,
I will swear you were a maid when I first lay with ye.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Pray do not swear, I thought I was a maid too,
But we may both be cozened in that point Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: In such a strait point sure I could not err Madam.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: This is another tenderness to try him,
Fetch her up now.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: You must provide a cradle, and what a trouble is that?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The sea shall rock it,
It is the best nurse; it will roar and rock together,
A swinging storm will sing you such a lullaby.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Faith let me stay, I shall but shame ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If you were a thousand shames you shall along with me,
At home I am sure you will prove a million,
Every man carries the bundle of his sins
Upon his own back, you are mine, I will sweat for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What Sir, preparing for your noble journey?
It is well, and full of care.
I saw your mind was wedded to the war,
And knew you would prove some good man for your country,
Therefore fair Cousin with your gentle pardon,
I got this place: what, mourn at his advancement?
You are to blame, he will come again sweet cousin,
Mean time like sad Penelope and sage,
Amongst your maids at home, and housewifely.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No Sir, I dare not leave her to that solitariness,
She is young, and grief or ill news from those quarters
May daily cross her, she shall go along Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: By no means Captain.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By all means if it please ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What take a young and tender bodied Lady,
And expose her to those dangers, and those tumults,
A sickly Lady too?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It will make her well Sir,
There is no such friend to health as wholesome travel.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Away it must not be.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: It ought not Sir,
Go hurry her? it is not human, Captain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot blame her tears, fright her with tempests,
With thunder of the war.
I dare swear if she were able.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She is most able.
And pray ye swear not, she must go, there is no remedy,
Nor greatness, nor the trick you had to part us,
Which I smell too rank, too open, too evident
(And I must tell you Sir, it is most unnoble)
Shall hinder me: had she but ten hours life,
Nay less, but two hours, I would have her with me,
I would not leave her fame to so much ruin,
To such a desolation and discredit
As her weakness and your hot will would work her to.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What Masque is this now?
More tropes and figures, to abuse my sufferance,
What cousin is this?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Michael van owl, how dost thou?
In what dark barn or tod of aged Ivy
Hast thou lain hid?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Things must both ebb and slow, Colonel,
And people must conceal, and shine again.
You are welcome hither as your friend may say, Gentleman,
A pretty house ye see handsomely seated,
Sweet and convenient walks, the waters crystal.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: He is certain mad.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: As mad as a French Tailor,
That has nothing in his head but ends of fustians.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I see you are packing now my gentle cousin,
And my wife told me I should find it so,
It is true I do, you were merry when I was last here,
But it was your will to try my patience Madam.
I am sorry that my swift occasions
Can let you take your pleasure here no longer,
Yet I would have you think my honoured cousin,
This house and all I have are all your servants.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What house, what pleasure Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You hold the jest so stiff, it will prove discourteous,
This house I mean, the pleasures of this place.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And what of them?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: They are mine Sir, and you know it,
My wifes I mean, and so conferred upon me;
The hangings Sir I must entreat, your servants,
That are so busy in their offices,
Again to minister to their right uses,
I shall take view of the plate anon, and furnitures
That are of under place; you are merry still cousin,
And of a pleasant constitution,
Men of great fortunes make their mirths at placitum.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Prithee good stubborn wife, tell me directly,
Good evil wife leave fooling and tell me honestly,
Is this my kinsman?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I can tell ye nothing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have many kinsmen, but so mad a one,
And so fantastic -- all the house?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All mine,
And all within it. I will not bate ye an ace on it.
Can you not receive a noble courtesy,
And quietly and handsomely as ye aught Cuz,
But you must ride on the top of it?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Canst thou fight?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will tell ye presently, I could have done Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: For ye must law and claw before ye get it.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Away, no quarrels.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Now I am more temperate,
I will have it proved if you were never yet in Bedlam,
Never in love, for that is a lunacy,
No great state left ye that you never looked for,
Nor cannot manage, that is a rank distemper;
That you were christened, and who answered for ye,
And then I yield.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He has half persuaded me I was bred in the moon,
I have never a bush at my breech, are not we both mad,
And is not this a fantastic house we are in,
And all a dream we do? will ye walk out Sir,
And if I do not beat thee presently
Into a sound belief, as sense can give thee,
Brick me into that wall there for a chimney piece,
And say I was one of the Csars done by a seal-cutter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will talk no more, come we will away immediately.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Why then the house is his, and all that is in it,
I will give away my skin but I will undo ye,
I gave it to his wife, you must restore Sir,
And make a new provision.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Am I mad now or am I christened, you my pagan cousin,
My mighty Mahound kinsman, what quirk now?
You shall be welcome all, I hope to see Sir
Your Grace here, and my cuz, we are all Soldiers,
And must do naturally for one another.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are ye blank at this? then I must tell ye Sir,
Ye have no command, now ye may go at pleasure
And ride your ass troop, it was a trick I used
To try your jealousy upon entreaty,
And saving of your wife.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: All this not moves me,
Nor stirs my gall, nor alters my affections,
You have more furniture, more houses Lady,
And rich ones too, I will make bold with those,
And you have Land in the Indies as I take it,
Thither we will go, and view a while those climates,
Visit your Factors there, that may betray ye,
It is done, we must go.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Now thou art a brave Gentleman,
And by this sacred light I love thee dearly.
The house is none of yours, I did but jest Sir,
Nor you are no cuz of mine, I beseech ye vanish,
I tell you plain, you have no more right than he
Has, that senseless thing, your wife has once more fooled ye:
Go ye and consider.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good morrow my sweet cousin, I should be glad Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By this hand she dies for it,
Or any man that speaks for her.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: These are fine toys.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Let me request you stay but one poor month,
You shall have a Commission and I will go too,
Give me but will so far.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Well I will try ye,
Good morrow to your Grace, we have private business.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If I miss thee again, I am an arrant bungler.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Thou shalt have my command, and I will march under thee,
Nay be thy boy before thou shalt be baffled,
Thou art so brave a fellow.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I have seen visions.

div1.stage: Enter Leon with a letter, and Margarita.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come hither wife, do you know this hand?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I do Sir,
It is Estifania that was once my woman.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She writes to me here, that one Cacafogo
An usuring Jewellers son (I know the Rascal)
Is mortally fallen in love with ye.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Is a monster, deliver me from mountains.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Do you go a-birding for all sorts of people?
And this evening will come to ye and show ye Jewels,
And offers anything to get access to ye,
If I can make or sport or profit on him,
(For he is fit for both) she bids me use him,
And so I will, be you conformable, and follow but my will.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I shall not fail, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Will the Duke come again do you think?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: No sure Sir,
He has now no policy to bring him hither.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nor bring you to him, if my wit hold fair wife:
Let us in to dinner.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Had I but lungs enough to bawl sufficiently,
That all the queans in Christendom might hear me,
That men might run away from contagion,
I had my wish; would it were most high treason,
Most infinite high, for any man to marry,
I mean for any man that would live handsomely,
And like a Gentleman, in his wits and credit.
What torments shall I put her to, Phalaris bull now?
Pox they love bulling too well, though they smoke for it.
Cut her apieces? every piece will live still,
And every morsel of her will do mischief;
They have so many lives, there is no hanging of them,
They are too light to drown, they are cork and feathers;
To burn too cold, they live like Salamanders;
Under huge heaps of stones to bury her,
And so depress her as they did the Giants;
She will move under more than built old Babel,
I must destroy her.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Be cozened by a thing of clouts, a she moth,
That every silkman's shop breeds; to be cheated,
And of a thousand ducats by a whim wham?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Who is that is cheated, speak again thou vision,
But art thou cheated? minister some comfort:
Tell me directly art thou cheated bravely?
Come, prithee come, art thou so pure a coxcomb
To be undone? do not dissemble with me,
Tell me I conjure thee.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Then keep thy circle,
For I am a spirit wild that flies about thee,
And whoever thou art, if thou beest human,
I will let thee plainly know, I am cheated damnably.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Dost thou laugh? damnably, I say most damnably.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By whom, good spirit speak, speak ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I will utter, laugh till thy lungs crack, by a rascal woman,
A lewd, abominable, and plain woman.
Dost thou laugh still?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I must laugh, prithee pardon me,
I shall laugh terribly.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I shall be angry, terrible angry, I have cause.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That is it, and it is no reason but thou shouldst be angry,
Angry at heart, yet I must laugh still at thee.
By a woman cheated? art sure it was a woman?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I shall break thy head, my valour itches at thee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It is no matter, by a woman cozened,
A real woman?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: A real Devil,
Plague of her Jewels and her copper chains,
How rank they smell.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sweet cozened Sir let me see them,
I have been cheated too, I would have you note that,
And lewdly cheated, by a woman also,
A scurvy woman, I am undone sweet Sir,
Therefore I must have leave to haugh.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Pray ye take it,
You are the merriest undone man in Europe.
What need we fiddles, bawdy songs and sack,
When our own miseries can make us merry?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
I have seen these Jewels, what a notable pennyworth
Have you had next your heart? you will not take Sir
Some twenty Ducats?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Thou art deceived, I will take.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: To clear your bargain now.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I will take some ten, some anything, some half ten,
Half a Ducat

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: An excellent lapidary set these stones sure,
Do you mark their waters?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Quick sand choke their waters,
And hers that bought them too, but I shall find her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And so shall I, I hope, but do not hurt her,
You cannot find in all this Kingdom,
(If you had need of cozening, as you may have,
For such gross natures will desire it often,
It is at some time too a fine variety,)
A woman that can cozen ye so neatly,
She has taken half mine anger off with this trick.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: If I were valiant now, I would kill this fellow,
I have money enough lies by me at a pinch
To pay for twenty Rascals lives that vex me,
I will to this Lady, there I shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come, we will away unto your country house,
And there we will learn to live contentedly,
This place is full of charge, and full of hurry,
No part of sweetness dwells about these cities.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Whither you will, I wait upon your pleasure;
Live in a hollow tree Sir, I will live with ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Aye , now you strike a harmony, a true one,
When your obedience waits upon your Husband,
And your sick will aims at the care of honour,
Why now I dote upon ye, love ye dearly,
And my rough nature falls like roaring streams,
Clearly and sweetly into your embraces.
O what a Jewel is a woman excellent,
A wise, a virtuous and a noble woman!
When we meet such, we bear our stamps on both sides,
And through the world we hold our currant virtues,
Alone we are single medals, only faces,
And wear our fortunes out in useless shadows,
Command you now, and ease me of that trouble,
I will be as humble to you as a servant,
Bid whom you please, invite your noble friends,
They shall be welcome all, visit acquaintance,
Go at your pleasure, now experience
Has linked you fast unto the chain of goodness:

div1.stage: Clashing swords. A cry within, down with their swords.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What noise is this, what dismal cry?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: It is loud too.
Sure there is some mischief done in the street, look out there.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Look out and help.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: O Sir the Duke Medina?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What of the Duke Medina?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: O sweet Gentleman, is almost slain.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Away away and help him, all the house help.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How slain? why Margarita,
Why wife, sure some new device they have afoot again,
Some trick upon my credit, I shall meet it,
I had rather guide a ship imperial
Alone, and in a storm, than rule one woman.

div1.stage: Enter Duke, Margarita, Sanchio, Alonzo Servant.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: How came ye hurt Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I fell out with my friend the noble Colonel,
My cause was naught, for it was about your honour:
And he that wrongs the Innocent never prospers,
And he has left me thus for charity,
Lend me a bed to ease my tortured body,
That ere I perish I may show my penitence,
I fear I am slain.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Help Gentlemen to carry him,
There shall be nothing in this house my Lord,
But as your own.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I thank ye noble Sir,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To bed with him, and wife give your attendance.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Doctors and Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Do not disquiet me,
But let me take my leave in peace.

div1.stage: Ex. Duke, Sanchio, Alon. Marg. Servant.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Afore me
It is rarely counterfeited.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: True, it is so Sir,
And take you heed, this last blow do not spoil ye,
He is not hurt, only we made a scuffle,
As though we purposed anger; that same scratch
On his hand he took, to colour all and draw compassion,
That he might get into your house more cunningly.
I must not stay, stand now, and you are a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank ye noble Colonel, and I honour ye.
Never be quiet?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: He is most desperate ill Sir,
I do not think these ten months will recover him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Does he hire my house to play the fool in,
Or does it stand on Fairy ground, we are haunted,
Are all men and their wives troubled with dreams thus?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: What ail you Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nay what ail you sweet wife,
To put these daily pastimes on my patience?
What dost thou see in me, that I should suffer thus,
Have not I done my part like a true Husband,
And paid some desperate debts you never looked for?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: You have done handsomely I must confess Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Have I not kept thee waking like a hawk?
And watched thee with delights to satisfy thee?
The very tithes of which had won a Widow.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Alas I pity ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me angry,
Thou never sawest me mad yet.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: You are always,
You carry a kind of bedlam still about ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If thou pursuest me further I run stark mad,
If you have more hurt Dukes or Gentlemen,
To lie here on your cure, I shall be desperate,
I know the trick, and you shall feel I know it,
Are ye so hot that no hedge can contain ye?
I will have thee let blood in all the veins about thee,
I will have thy thoughts sound too, and have them opened,
Thy spirits purged, for those are they that fire ye,
Thy maid shall be thy Mistress, thou the maid,
And all those servile labours that she reach at,
And go through cheerfully, or else sleep empty,
That maid shall lie by me to teach you duty,
You in a pallet by to humble ye,
And grieve for what you lose.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I have lost myself Sir,
And all that was my base self, disobedience,

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: My wantonness, my stubbornness I have lost too,
And now by that pure faith good wives are crowned with,
By your own nobleness.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I take ye up, and wear ye next my heart,
See you be worth it. Now what with you?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I come to tell my Lady,
There is a fulsome fellow would fain speak with her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It is Cacafogo go and entertain him,
And draw him on with hopes.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I shall observe ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have a rare design upon that Gentleman,
And you must work too.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I shall Sir most willingly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Away then both, and keep him close in some place.
From the Dukes sight, and keep the Duke in too,
Make them believe both, I will find time to cure them.

div1.stage: Enter Perez, and Estifania, with a Pistol, and a Dagge.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why how darest thou meet me again thou rebel,
And knowest how thou hast used me thrice, thou rascal?
Were there not ways enough to fly my vengeance,
No holes nor vaults to hide thee from my fury,
But thou must meet me face to face to kill thee?
I would not seek thee to destroy thee willingly,
But now thou comest to invite me,
And comest upon me,
How like a sheep-biting Rogue taken in the manner,
And ready for the halter dost thou look now?
Thou hast a hanging look thou scurvy thing, hast never a knife
Nor ever a string to lead thee to Elysium?
Be there no pitiful Apothecaries in this town,
That have compassion upon wretched women,
And dare administer a dram of rats-bane,
But thou must fall to me?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I know you have mercy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If I had tuns of mercy thou deservest none,
What new trick is now afoot , and what new houses
Have you in the air, what orchards in apparition,
What canst thou say for thy life?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Little or nothing,
I know you will kill me, and I know it is useless
To beg for mercy, pray let me draw my book out,
And pray a little.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Do, a very little,
For I have farther business than thy killing,
I have money yet to borrow, speak when you are ready.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Now now Sir, now,

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Come on, do you start off from me,
Do you swear great Captain, have you seen a spirit?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Do you wear guns?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I am a Soldiers wife Sir,
And by that privilege I may be armed,
Now what is the news, and let us discourse more friendly,
And talk of our affairs in peace.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let me see,
Prithee let me see thy gun, it is a very pretty one.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: No no Sir, you shall feel.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hold ye villain, what thine own Husband?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Let mine own Husband then
Be in his own wits, there, there is a thousand ducats,
Who must provide for you, and yet you will kill me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will not hurt thee for ten thousand millions.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: When will you redeem your Jewels, I have pawned them,
You see for what, we must keep touch.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will kiss thee,
And get as many more, I will make thee famous,
Had we the house now!

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Come along with me,
If that be vanished there be more to hire Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I see I am an ass when thou art near me.

div1.stage: Enter Leon, Margarita, and Altea, with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Is the fool come?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Yes and in the cellar fast,
And there he stays his good hour till I call him,
He will make dainty music among the sack-butts,
I have put him just, Sir, under the Dukes chamber.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It is the better.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Has given me royally,
And to my Lady a whole load of portigues.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Better and better still, go Margarita,
Now play your prize, you say you dare be honest,
I will put ye to your best.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Secure yourself Sir, give me the candle,
Pass away in silence.

div1.stage: Ex. Leon, and Altea She knocks.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who is there, O, O .

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: My Lord.
Have ye brought me comfort?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I have my Lord,
Come forth it is I, come gently out I will help ye,

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Come softly too, how do you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are there none here?
Let me look round; we cannot be too wary,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O let me bless this hour, are you alone sweet friend?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Alone to comfort you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What is that you tumble?
I have heard a noise this half hour under me,
A fearful noise.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: The fat thing is mad in the cellar,
And stumbles from one hogs-head to another,
Two cups more, and he never shall find the way out.
What do you fear? come, sit down by me cheerfully,
My Husband is safe, how do your wounds?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I have none Lady,
My wounds I counterfeited cunningly,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And feigned the quarrel too, to enjoy you sweet,
Let us lose no time, hark the same noise again.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: What noise, why look ye pale? I hear no stirring,
This goblin in the vault will be so tippled.
You are not well I know by your flying fancy,
Your body is ill at ease, your wounds.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I have none, I am as lusty and as full of health,
High in my blood.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Weak in your blood you would say,
How wretched is my case, willing to please ye,
And find you so disable?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Believe me Lady.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I know you will venture all you have to satisfy me,
Your life I know, but is it fit I spoil ye,
Is it my love do you think?
Here is to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It named me certainly,
I heard it plainly sound.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: You are hurt mortally,
And fitter for your prayers Sir than pleasure,
What starts you make? I would not kiss you wantonly,
For the worlds wealth; have I secured my Husband,
And put all doubts aside to be deluded?
I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven bless me.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: And bless us both, for sure this is the Devil,
I plainly heard it now, he will come to fetch ye,
A very spirit, for he spoke under ground,
And spoke to you just as you would have snatched me,
You are a wicked man, and sure this haunts ye,
Would you were out of the house.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I would I were,
On that condition I had leapt a window.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: And that is the least leap if you mean to scape Sir,
Why what a frantic man were you to come here,
What a weak man to counterfeit deep wounds,
To wound another deeper?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are you honest then?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Yes then and now, and ever, and excellent honest,
And exercise this pastime but to show ye,
Great men are fools sometimes as well as wretches.
Would you were well hurt, with any hope of life,
Cut to the brains, or run clean through the body,
To get out quietly as you got in Sir,
I wish it like a friend that loves ye dearly,
For if my Husband take ye, and take ye thus a counterfeit,
One that would clip his credit out of his honour,
He must kill ye presently,
There is no mercy nor an hour of pity,
And for me to entreat in such an agony,
Would show me little better than one guilty,
Have you any mind to a Lady now?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Would I were off fair,
If ever Lady caught me in a trap more.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: If you be well and lusty, fie fie shake not,
You say you love me, come, come bravely now,
Despise all danger, I am ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: She mocks my misery, thou cruel Lady.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Thou cruel Lord, wouldst thou betray my honesty,
Betray it in mine own house, wrong my Husband,
Like a night thief, thou darest not name by day-light?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am most miserable.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: You are indeed,
And like a foolish thing you have made yourself so,
Could not your own discretion tell ye Sir,
When I was married I was none of yours?
Your eyes were then commanded to look off me,
And I now stand in a circle and secure,
Your spells nor power can never reach my body,
Mark me but this, and then Sir be most miserable,
It is sacrilege to violate a wedlock,
You rob two Temples, make yourself twice guilty,
You ruin hers, and spot her noble Husbands.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let me be gone, I will never more attempt ye.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: You cannot go, it is not in me to save ye,
Dare ye do ill, and poorly then shrink under it?
Were I the Duke Medina I would fight now,
For you must fight and bravely, it concerns you,
You do me double wrong if you sneak off Sir,
And all the world would say I loved a coward,
And you must die too, for you will be killed,
And leave your youth, your honour and your state,
And all those dear delights you worshipped here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The noise again
Some small beer if you love me.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: The Devil haunts you sure, your sins are mighty.
A drunken Devil too, to plague your villainy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Preserve me but this once.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: There is a deep well
In the next yard, if you dare venture drowning,
It is but death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I would not die so wretchedly.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Out of a garret window I will let you down then,
But say the rope be rotten, it is huge high too.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Have you no mercy?

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Now you are frighted thoroughly,
And find what it is to play the fool in folly,
And see with clear eyes your detested folly,
I will be your guard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And I will be your true servant,
Ever from this hour virtuously to love ye,
Chastely and modestly to look upon ye,
And here I seal it.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: I may kiss a stranger, for you must now be so.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How do you my Lord,
Methinks you look but poorly on this matter.
Has my wife wounded ye, you were well before,
Pray Sir be comforted, I have forgot all,
Truly forgiven too, wife you are a right one,
And now with unknown nations I dare trust ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: No more feigned fights my Lord, they never prosper.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who is this? the Devil in the vault?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: It is he Sir, and as lovingly drunk, as though he had studied it.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Give me a cup of Sack, and kiss me Lady,
Kiss my sweet face, and make thy Husband cuckold,
An Ocean of sweet Sack, shall we speak treason?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He is Devilish drunk.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I had thought he had been a Devil.
He made as many noises and as horrible.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O a true love Sir will lament loudly,
Which of the butts is your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Butt in thy belly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There is two in thine I am sure, it is grown so monstrous.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Butt in thy face.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Go carry him to sleep,
A fools love should be drunk, he has paid well for it too.
When he is sober let him out to rail,
Or hang himself, there will be no loss of him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who is this? my Manhound cousin?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Good Sir, it is very good, would I had a house too,
For there is no talking in the open air,
My Termagant Cuz, I would be bold to tell ye,
I durst be merry too, I tell you plainly,
You have a pretty seat, you have the luck on it,
A pretty Lady too, I have missed both,
My Carpenter built in a mist I thank him,
Do me the courtesy to let me see it,
See it but once more. But I shall cry for anger.
I will hire a Chandlers shop close under ye,
And for my foolery, sell soap and whip-cord,
Nay if you do not laugh now and laugh heartily,
You are a fool cuz.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I must laugh a little,
And now I have done, cuz thou shalt live with me,
My merry cuz, the world shall not divorce us,
Thou art a valiant man, and thou shalt never want,
Will this content thee?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will cry, and then, I will be thankful,
Indeed I will, and I will be honest to ye.
I would live a swallow here I must confess.
Wife I forgive thee all if thou be honest,
At thy peril, I believe thee excellent.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: If I prove otherways, let me beg first,
Hold, this is yours, some recompense for service,
Use it to nobler ends than he that gave it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And this is yours, your true commission, Sir,
Now you are a Captain.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You are a noble Prince Sir,
And now a soldier, Gentleman, we all rejoice in it.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Sir, I shall wait upon you through all fortunes.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: And I must needs attend my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Will you go Sister?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Yes indeed good Brother,
I have two ties, mine own blood,
And my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Is she your Sister?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes indeed good wife,
And my best Sister,
For she proved so, wench,
When she deceived you with a loving Husband.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I would not deal so truly for a stranger.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Well I could chide ye,
But it must be lovingly and like a Sister,
I will bring you on your way, and feast ye nobly,
For now I have an honest heart to love ye,
And then deliver you to the blue Neptune.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Your colours you must wear, and wear them proudly,
Wear them before the bullet, and in blood too,
And all the world shall know
We are Vertues servants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And all the world shall know, a noble mind
Makes women beautiful, and envy blind.
Pleasure attend ye, and about ye sit
The springs of mirth, fancy, delight and wit
To stir you up, do not your looks let fall,
Nor to remembrance our late errors call,
Because this day we are Spaniards all again,
The story of our Play, and our Scene Spain :
The errors too, do not for this cause hate,
Now we present their wit and not their state.
Nor Ladies be not angry if you see,
A young fresh beauty, wanton and too free,
Seek to abuse her Husband, still it is Spain ,
No such gross errors in your Kingdom reign,
We are Vestals all, and though we blow the fire,
We seldom make it flame up to desire,
Take no example neither to begin,
For some by precedent delight to sin:
Nor blame the Poet if he slip aside
Sometimes lasciviously if not too wide.
But hold your Fans close, and then smile at ease,
A cruel Scene did never Lady please.
Nor Gentlemen, pray be not you displeased,
Though we present some men fooled, some diseased,
Some drunk, some mad: we mean not you, you are free,
We tax no farther than our Comedy,
You are our friends, sit noble then and see.
Good night our worthy friends, and may you part
Each with as merry and as free a heart
As you came hither; to those noble eyes
That deign to smile on our poor faculties,
And give a blessing to our labouring ends,
As we hope many, to such fortune sends
Their own desires, wives fair as light as chaste;
To those that live by spite Wives made in hast.
